lead_paragraph: A study by the agency found that the practice, long known as a ritual in Africa and parts of the Middle East, included almost half the women of Indonesia.

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and JOE COCHRANE

headline.print_headline: Female Genital Cutting: Not Just ‘an African Problem’
headline.main: Unicef Report Finds Female Genital Cutting to Be Common in Indonesia

snippet: A study by the agency found that the practice, long known as a ritual in Africa and parts of the Middle East, included almost half the women of Indonesia.
abstract: New Unicef report claims almost half of all Indonesian women have undergone female genital mutilation; confirms practice is not confined to Africa and parts of Middle East, but is declining globally; country's government struggles to reconcile campaign to eradicate practice with lingering popular support for traditional Islamic rite.
